awd_titl_txt: Convergence Accelerator Phase I: Accelerating the Bioeconomy: Transformation of Engineering Biology through Public Biofoundries
awd_abstract_narration:
The workshop will bring together key stakeholder from academia, industry and government with the charge of identifying the best ways to leverage public biofoundries to accelerate engineering biology, towards applications in biomanufacturing and other means to accelerate the bioeconomy and technology translation.  

The road to achieving a bio-based economy is transitioning from a concept to a tangible reality and it is acknowledged that public bio-foundries would have a role in enabling the technology that would drive such an economy. This proposal describes activities that are timely for the rapid acceleration of the commercialization of biotechnology. 

The end result of the workshop should be a report summarizing the workshop proceedings along with a set of recommendations for future coordination and collaboration between investigators and public biofoundries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

por.por_cntn:
The U.S. bioeconomy is valued at over $1 trillion per year, about 5% of the U.S. GDP, and is anticipated to continue to vigorously grow through 2030.

While U.S. Agencies such as the NSF currently invest between $100-200 million in individual investigator projects in synthetic/engineering biology, most of these projects never proceed beyond the proof of concept stage, and never contribute materially to the bioeconomy.

There is an infrastructure that is being developed in biofoundries, with available capacity that has been demonstrated in a small number of projects, able to accelerate the pace of development by 10-100 fold. But designing experiments for biofoundries, and thinking about this new model for research, is not part of the culture of research in biotechnology today.

This workshop was designed to enable experts from academia, public biofoundries, industry, and US Government Agencies to examine several case studies in how public biofoundry infrastructure has been or could be leveraged to accelerate topical areas of engineering biology research/applications, to identify gaps and opportunities for further and expanded coordination and collaboration, to enable the acceleration of engineering biology and of the bioeconomy as a whole.

The workshop contributed to the acceleration of the bioeconomy and the transformation of engineering biology through public biofoundries, by bringing together a leading group of experts from academia (whose research and development efforts would be accelerated and transformed), public biofoundries (whose domain expertise and infrastructure would be leveraged), and the private sector/industry (who would also be contributing to the engineering biology ecosystem). The meeting provided the foundation for increased collaboration and coordination among US Agencies, the investigators and biofoundries that these US Agencies support, and industry. In addition, this proceedings report will be publicly released and disseminated. The workshop’s organizers ensured that the workshop included attendees from underrepresented groups in Science and Technology and attendees who are at all stages of their career.

This workshop brought together 15 representatives from US Government Agencies and a group of 31 experts from academia, public biofoundries, and industry, for a 2 day workshop (see APPENDIX for meeting agenda and attendee list). The overall objective for the workshop was to help identify the best ways to leverage public biofoundries to accelerate engineering biology, towards applications in biomanufacturing and other means to accelerate the bioeconomy and technology translation
The motivational research and development talks and representative collaboration case studies presented in this workshop discussed specific success stories, highlighting the power of the approach. The breakout sessions and aggregate participant recommendations then laid out the opportunities and challenges identified in the workshop

 


Last Modified: 02/07/2023
Modified by: Henrik V Scheller
